conclusion: Identify every process of the Stirling cycle in the P-V plot
A → B is isothermal expansion at the high temperature TH (heat absorbed)
B → C is isochoric (constant-V) cooling; temperature falls from TH to TL
C → D is isothermal compression at the low temperature TL (heat rejected)
D → A is isochoric heating; temperature rises from TL back to TH
Recall the microscopic meaning of the Maxwell-Boltzmann speed-distribution curve
For an ideal monatomic gas the (one-dimensional) speed distribution is f(v,T) = 4π(m/2πkT)^(3/2) v² e^{−mv²/2kT}, where T is the absolute temperature.
When T increases, the most-probable speed vmp = √(2kT/m) shifts to the right (higher speed).
The curve flattens out and broadens because a larger fraction of molecules possess higher speeds.
The shape of the distribution curve depends only on T; it is independent of p and V separately.

premise: Along D → A the volume is kept constant (isochoric), but external heating raises the gas temperature from TL (at D) to TH (at A).
conclusion: Since TL < TH, the temperature at A is higher than at D.

premise: Because the temperature is different, the Maxwell speed-distribution curve must change.
conclusion: Peak position vmp increases (shifts to higher speeds).

premise: Because the temperature is different, the Maxwell speed-distribution curve must change.
conclusion: Peak value fmax decreases (curve is lower and wider).

premise: Because the temperature is different, the Maxwell speed-distribution curve must change.
conclusion: Tail of the distribution becomes “heavier”—more molecules acquire higher speeds.

premise: Isochoric ⇒ n and V remain unchanged.
conclusion: Internal energy ΔU = nCvΔT > 0; therefore T increases.

premise: A higher T modifies every temperature-dependent quantity, including the molecular speed distribution.
conclusion: During the constant-volume heating D → A the temperature rises from TL to TH, so the Maxwell–Boltzmann speed-distribution curve is altered: it shifts to higher speeds and becomes broader.
